p: Binary transition metal oxides (TMOs), owing to their high capacity (e.g., ZnFeO 2—700 mAh/g, ZnCo 2O 4—867 mAh/g, NiCoO 2—716 mAh/g, NiCo 2O 4—891 mAh/g), are very promising materials for producing SSLIB anodes. However, low conductivity and relatively high-volume change during cycling are the main challenges limiting their use [ 6, 7]. To overcome these challenges, it is necessary to utilize various nanostructures that are more stable with repeated cycling than bulk materials of anodes [ 6, 8, 9]. Moreover, 2-D nanostructures, called nanofilms, can be used for producing thin-film SSLIBs to minimize the size of electronic devices.
